bioghist.p: Socialist Review is a left-wing political and cultural journal. It began publication in January 1970 as Socialist Revolution, led by New Left historian James Weinstein and edited by the collective Agenda Publishing Company in San Francisco. In 1977 the California collective merged with collectives in Boston and New York and the name of the periodical changed to Socialist Review. During this time editorial duties passed to David Plotke of Yale and Jeffrey Escoffier. Over time Nancy Chodorow, author of The Reproduction of Mothering and Howard Winant, co-author of Racial Formation in the United States, participated in the collective. In 2002 the journal's name was changed again, to Radical Society: A Review of Culture and Politics.

scopecontent.p: The archives of this 1970s leftist periodical includes correspondence, interviews, financial records, article drafts, newspaper clippings, and photographs. The materials represent both the Socialist Review and its predecessor, Socialist Revolution. The collection includes a detailed index of Numbers 1-96 and contributors, as well as unpublished manuscripts. The published manuscripts document issues such as feminism, gay rights, American labor laws and legislation, environmental protection, nuclear disarmament, socialism in the United States and France, and women's rights. The prominent correspondents include Nancy Chodorow, Noam Chomsky, Michel Foucault, Karl E. Klare, David Plotke, Albert Szymanski, James Weinstein, and Eli Zaretsky. There are also meeting minutes that note the editorial board's discussions of politics, strategy for the journal, and editorial decisions; financial documentation including budgets, grant proposals and reports, fundraising, insurance and tax information, and cash receipts and disbursements; copies of Socialist Revolution and Socialist Review (complete from vol. 1 #1, 1970, to vol. 19, # 3, 1989); and illustrations, and ad copy.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
